title: The Strange Power of Laughter
excerpt: An anthropologist explores laughter as a far more complex phenomenon than simple delight—reflecting on its surprising power to disturb and disrupt.

title: Why are some sounds funny?
excerpt: To English speakers, the word, “peanut” isn’t especially funny. But “peanut” in Serbian, “kikiriki” is widely considered by Serbs to be the funniest word in their language. This raises the question of why people laugh at some words (“poop”) but not at others (“treadmill”). Does it come down to their meanings? Or are people responding to their sounds? Psycholinguist Chris Westbury set out to discover the answer.

title: The surprising power of memes
excerpt: The science of these viral mash-ups reveals why they are so effective at spreading ideas and beliefs.

title: What’s So Funny? The Science of Why We Laugh
excerpt: Psychologists, neuroscientists and philosophers are trying to understand humor.

title: Mapping How to Laugh Online in Different Languages
excerpt: In this map of laughter around the world you will be able to see how haha is written in different countries depending on their languages.

title: With ‘The Far Side,’ Gary Larson Pioneered the Art of the Meme
excerpt: There couldn’t be a ‘Is This a Pigeon?’ without a ‘Beware of Doug’.

title: What's the funniest name you've heard someone call an object when they couldn't remember its actual name?
excerpt: 24K votes, 10K comments. 49M subscribers in the AskReddit community. r/AskReddit is the place to ask and answer thought-provoking questions.
